question:
Find the union of each of the following pairs of sets:
(i) $X = \{2, 4, 6\}, Y = \{1, 2, 3\}$
(ii) $P = \{a, b, c\}, Q = \{c, d, e\}$
(iii) $M = \{x : x \text{ is a natural number and multiple of 2}\}, N = \{x : x \text{ is a natural number and multiple of 5}\}$
(iv) $A = \{x : x \text{ is a natural number and } 2 < x \le 5\}, B = \{x : x \text{ is a natural number and } 5 < x < 9\}$
(v) $E = \{1, 2, 3\}, F = \phi$
Let $P = \{x, y\}, Q = \{x, y, z\}$. Is $P \subset Q$? What is $P \cup Q$?
solutionSteps: Every element of P is in Q, so $P \subset Q$ is True.

question: If A and B are two sets such that $A \subset B$, then what is $A \cap B$?
solutionSteps: If A is a subset of B, all elements of A are in B.
The common elements between A and B are exactly the elements of A.

question:
If $A = \{1, 2\}, B = \{2, 3, 4\}, C = \{4, 5\}$ and $D = \{5, 6, 7\}$; find:
(i) $A \cup B$
(ii) $A \cup C$
(iii) $B \cup C$
(iv) $B \cup D$
(v) $A \cup B \cup C$
(vi) $A \cup B \cup D$
(vii) $B \cup C \cup D$
Find the intersection of each pair of sets of Question 1 above.
solutionSteps: (iii) Multiples of 2 and 5 are multiples of 10. $M \cap N = \{10, 20, 30, ...\}$

question:
If $A = \{2, 4, 6, 8\}, B = \{6, 8, 10, 12\}, C = \{10, 12, 14\}$ and $D = \{14, 16\}$; find:
(i) $A \cap B$
(ii) $B \cap C$
(iii) $A \cap C \cap D$
(iv) $A \cap C$
(v) $B \cap D$
(vi) $A \cap (B \cup C)$
(vii) $A \cap D$
(viii) $B \cap (C \cup D)$
(ix) $(A \cap B) \cap (B \cup C)$
(x) $(A \cup D) \cap (B \cup C)$

If $A = \{x : x \text{ is a multiple of 3}\}, B = \{x : x \text{ is a multiple of 4}\}, C = \{x : x \text{ is a multiple of 12}\}$ and $D = \{x : x \text{ is a prime number}\}$, find:
(i) $A \cap B$
(ii) $A \cap C$
(iii) $B \cap C$
(iv) $C \cap D$
solutionSteps: (i) Multiples of 3 and 4 are multiples of LCM(3,4)=12. So $A \cap B = C$.
(ii) Multiples of 3 and 12 are multiples of 12. $A \cap C = C$.
(iii) Multiples of 4 and 12 are multiples of 12. $B \cap C = C$.
(iv) Multiples of 12 are composite (except maybe if 12 was prime, which it isn't). No prime is a multiple of 12. $\phi$.

question:
Which of the following pairs of sets are disjoint?
(i) $\{a, b, c\}$ and $\{d, e, f\}$
(ii) $\{2, 4, 6\}$ and $\{x : x \text{ is an odd integer}\}$
(iii) $\{x : x \text{ is a prime number}\}$ and $\{x : x \text{ is a composite number}\}$
solutionSteps: (ii) Even numbers and odd integers have no intersection. Disjoint.
(iii) Primes and composites are distinct definitions (assuming x > 1). Disjoint.

question:
If $A = \{1, 2, 3, 4, 5\}, B = \{4, 5, 6, 7\}, C = \{6, 7, 8, 9\}, D = \{7, 8\}$; find:
(i) $A - B$
(ii) $B - C$
(iii) $C - D$
(iv) $D - A$
solutionSteps: (i) Elements in A not in B: $\{1, 2, 3\}$
(ii) Elements in B not in C: $\{4, 5\}$
(iii) Elements in C not in D: $\{6, 9\}$
(iv) Elements in D not in A: $\{7, 8\}$

question:
If $X = \{p, q, r, s\}$ and $Y = \{r, s, t, u\}$, find:
(i) $X - Y$
(ii) $Y - X$
(iii) $X \cap Y$
solutionSteps: (i) Elements in X but not Y: $\{p, q\}$
(ii) Elements in Y but not X: $\{t, u\}$

question: If R is the set of real numbers and T is the set of irrational numbers, then what is $R - T$?
solutionSteps: Real numbers (R) consist of Rational (Q) and Irrational numbers (T).
Removing Irrational numbers from Real numbers leaves Rational numbers.

question:
State whether each of the following statement is true or false. Justify your answer.
(i) $\{1, 2, 3\}$ and $\{4, 5, 6\}$ are disjoint sets.
(ii) $\{a, e, i\}$ and $\{x, y, z, a\}$ are disjoint sets.
(iii) $\{2, 6, 10\}$ and $\{3, 7, 11\}$ are disjoint sets.
